ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned so much about the Asian diasporic experience. This class covers a lot of different aspects of this experience and from many different perspectives. It is truly one of my favorite classes I've taken here.
I learned about Asian diasporas since 1800, queer Asian diasporas, a lot of theory and history.
I gained knowledge about many different Asian diasporas around the world and how they adapted, formed, and maintained their cultures.
A framework with which to think about diasporic communities.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Sometimes the readings were a little heavylike many once-a-week seminars at Yale, there's just not enough time to cover everything you read. But I wouldn't necessarily have cut any of the content because it really gave us a big picture of the field of Asian diasporas. We also went on a really cool field trip at the start of the semester that brought us all closer. By the end, I left the class with a lot of new friends, and I think this can mostly be attributed to the positive environment that Professor Tran fosters in her classroom.

Strengths: Professor Tran is an amazing instructor. For me, I was not as interested in the global aspect of Asian diasporas. We spent a lot of time talking about Asian coolie laborers and theory, so it was not as engaging for me as I hoped, but the class was still enjoyable.

Strengths: readings were well organized and very insightful, discussions were thought-provoking and helpful in understanding the concept of diaspora 

Weaknesses: some weeks, the readings were extremely long and difficult to understand

Strengths were the readings and Professor Tran
Weakness were the seminar discussions - I often left class feeling like I did not really gain much from the discussions nor did they really feel entirely productive

Strengths: Professor Tran, the class community, the structure of the course
Areas of improvement: the reading load could be more balanced during the beginning of the semester

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Especially to anyone who has any interest in or personal connection to the Asian diaspora.

If you're interested in the history of Asia and theory like Lisa Lowe and are okay studying global context, then take the class! I think intro to critical refugee studies probably would have been a more enjoyable class that's tailored to my interests, but I still was able to explore my passions through this class!

Yes, Prof Tran is amazing at synthesizing discussion comments and providing powerful insight into the readings! This class was truly amazing and we grew extremely close as a class because we had field trips to exhibitions and our final projects were deeply personal. I would recommend any class with Prof Tram, especially this one!

Yes. I literally cannot recommend this class more highly. It could be the best class I've taken here and Prof Tran is the most amazing, caring professor ever. If you get the chance to take this class, do it.
Yes, but if you're willing to really do the readings and work to understand how they are connected. Prof. Tran has curated a fantastic list of readings.

Absolutely! Professor Tran is a fantastic instructor, and I learned a lot from the readings and assignments. I appreciated that the focus of the class was not solely on Asian migrants in the United States, which allowed for a more expansive and critical understanding of the term "Asian diaspora." The trip at the beginning of the semester really set the tone for the course; this was a class filled with joy, laughter, and meaningful connection. This course was well worth the early morning trek to HQ!
